One of the most characteristic, and perhaps most prominent features of our age, is the multiplication and circulation of periodical works. Whether they are more likely to be converted into objects of abuse or of utility; whether they are productive of more advantage or detriment to politics, morals, sciences, arts, letters and genius, are questions which we shall proceed to examine. At all events, the force of customs in this, as in every thing else, has triumphed over the arguments of the opponents of works of this kind, as well as over the prohibitory laws of despotic governments. Some princes have succeeded in imposing silence upon their subjects; but neither their censures nor their inquisitions, either religious or political, nor their arbitrary punishments, have ever been able to prevent the inhabitants, either of the palaces, the cottages, or the prisons of their dominions, from reading almost every thing that is written in other nations. In our days, the whole of Europe appears one immense assembly, in which many expose their opinions, and all listen with eagerness. To read, to think, and to reason, has become in the present day an irresistible necessity. That the generality of men, from being destined to an active rather than a speculative life, must necessarily read ill, think ill, and reason ill, is a truth too obvious to need any proof; it is equally obvious, that this new and increasing want, in augmenting the pleasures of mortals, subjects them at the same time to new hardships and sorrows.

Amurath IV following the example of all the princes of his time, had, under pain of death, interdicted the use of tobacco to all his subjects; it was his custom to make the circuit of Constantinople in disguise, thus filling the threefold capacity of spy, of judge, and sometimes of executioner, against the unfortunate smokers. But he found that the Turks were more resigned to the loss of their lives than of their smoking. — It would appear from the periodical works we continue to receive from Italy, that Austria; and all the viceroys of Austria, who, under the title of independent princes, govern the rest of the peninsula, wisely follow the example of the Ottoman emperor. The fact is, that Italy, though never so much a slave and so systematically condemned to silence as at present, possesses many more literary journals, and of greater merit, than she did thirty years since, when. freedom of writing and printing was not only tolerated, but encouraged and protected. Before the revolution, Italy was under the control of different princes, who, though, not at open war with each other, were not always on friendly terms; and many of these being independent, Naples for instances permission was there given to write freely respecting the temporal pretension of Rome; in Rome, against the political and ecclesiastical reform introduced by Austria; and in Venice an inquisitor of the holy office was appointed pro formâ, but the republic would allow him neither to imprison, to torture, nor even to examine those acoused of heresy. Sometimes the reverend father, in order not to violate the instructions received from Rome, would refuse the imprimatur to authors, but, after all, their books were printed and sold and, the approbation of the Venetian magistrates was sufficient to protect them from prosecution. The French Encyclopedia (sic), though put in the Pope's prohibited index, was publicly reprinted at Padua, for the use of the university. It might be thought, that in so many magnificent capitals of different states, each of which possessed an university, periodical works would multiply and come to perfection. But though many were undertaken, very few were continued; none of them were productive, and some ruinous to the undertakers; and they always fell into neglect, in consequence of those wretched animosities that exist between different provinces, from which, as from an unfailing spring, flow all the misfortunes of the Italians, and all the opprobrium that attaches to their name.

Wherever the epidemic of provincial jealousies and wretched dissensions prevails, even men of letters become infected by its influence; instead of speaking to the whole nation, they profess themselves the writers of a party; and, with a contemptible ambition, carry on a continual war of the pen in favour of the ridiculous prejudices of their province, of the particular methods pursued by their respective universities, and of the pretensions to pre–eminence maintained by their municipal academies. Independently of this misfortune, which is peculiar to Italy, and which has rendered the establishment of national periodical works an undertaking of such difficulty, the experience of all other countries shews, that although a literary journal be considered as inferior to many other works of talent, it is, however, an undertaking that requires more time, more study, and more perseverance, than any other; and which, with difficulty is carried even to the negative perfection of being more useful than hurtful.

Not the least trace of periodical works is discoverable among the Greeks and Romans. They had public registers, in which were daily recorded, in a very brief manner, such events as were judged worthy of being transmitted to posterity. Under the emperors frequent mention is found of Diarii, which appear to have resembled in a great degree the official gazettes of modern governments; and it appears, that amidst the flattery and exaggerations inseparable from court registers kept in this manner, were contained many facts useful to history: hence Tacitus frequently refers to the Diarii as documents, if not authentic, at least probably correct. But while this kind of journal was employed to enregister civil and political notices, and the anecdotes of the day, it does not appear to have contained any accounts relative to literature. The difficulty of having a sufficient number of copies transcribed to supply the rapid circulation necessary to a periodical publication — a difficulty which the art of printing alone can obviate — must of itself have been sufficient to discourage the idea of compiling a journal. But it does not appear probable that any of the ancients had conceived the possibility of such an undertaking. Nor will this be deemed a matter of wonder, when we recollect that the typographic art had flourished nearly tow centuries throughout all Europe before literature possessed a single literary journal. The Italians, who were certainly the first to set the example in almost every species of literature, must renounce the praise of having been the inventors of periodical works. An attention to dates will shew, that England and France only have a right to claim the merit of priority, which, to be impartial, appears to belong to the French. The Journal des Savants , and the Philosophical Transactions, were undertaken and published, the first in France, and the other in England, in the same year (1665). But the
Journal des Savants had a more popular object, and all the essential requisites of a periodical publication, while the Philosophical Transactions appear to have been exclusively intended for scientific men and public establishments. The articles of the French journalists did not, at the commencement, equal the merit of the dissertations of the English philosophers; but the English collection, without falling off from its first reputation, exhibited but few ameliorations, whilst the Journal des Savants acquired vigour with years, and was, for a very long period, regarded as the most enlightened tribunal of letters and sciences.

The Italians, like all nations and individuals who have fallen from their ancient splendour, console their vanity by recurring to the memory of days gone by, and not unfrequently by exaggerating the merits of their forefathers; and although they cannot deny that their first periodical works were posterior to those of France and England, yet they contend that Europe is indebted for at least the first idea of this species of literature to Antonio Doni, a native of Florence, who, towards the middle of the sixteenth century, compiled extracts from a variety of books, and criticized, not only all the productions of his contemporaries, but also those inedited works to which he was able to gain access. He divided his work into two parts, and entitled it Librerie ; the first treats of printed books, the other of manuscripts. It cannot be denied that all those — and among them is the illustrious Bayle — who adopted the name of Bibliothèque for their literary journals, have in this particular imitated Doni. But their imitation, whether accidental or intentional, went no farther than the title, nor indeed was Doni worthy of being imitated in any other particular. He was a compound of ignorance, arrogance, and profligacy; he openly made profession of censuring or praising authors, according as he was paid for the same; he was ever ready to lay on the flattering unction of praise, or pour out the gall of bitterness, in proportion to a stipulated sum. He was a contemporary, and, in the first instance, a friend, though afterwards an enemy of Pietro Aretino, surnamed by the Italians l'Infame, a man who still continues to be spoken of much more than he deserves. Madame de Stael thought it her duty to visit the tomb of this Aretino, and make her meditations thereon; but these were sadly out of place in every respect, and in none more than in her imagining this tomb to contain the bones of an infamous writer, when, instead of it, it held the ashes of a great man who had been dead a century and a half before Pietro Aretino was born. This is a hint, en passant, to those travellers who return to their country enriched with classical notices, topographic sketches, and anecdotes, absolutely unknown to all the inhabitants of the countries traversed by these industrious tourists. But to return to Doni, though differing but little from Aretino in genius and disposition, yet he deserves to be less forgotten, inasmuch as he was one of the most strange and whimsical of human animals that the hand of nature had ever formed, and as his character is illustrative of the manners of the age in which he lived. Though member of a religious order, from whose convent the had run away, and though in virtue of the holy orders he had received, and of which he could not divest himself, he was still obliged to remain a priest, he openly laughed at religion, and stooped to gain a livelihood by the quackeries practised by the Catholic priestood. A few words from one of his letters will at once suffice to give an idea of his principles and of his style: — “Non ho un beneficio traditore al mondo, nè entrata d'un ladro: non scampano pro defunctis; et non canto
Gaudeamus ; et in vita mia non beccai mai un soldo nè di S. Gregorio, nè di S. Lazzaro: non scuffiai mai pagnotta, che non fosse sudata dal mio cervello”. This style, composed of words taken from the fish–market, and from the slang of pickpockets, possesses a certain energy and smartness through the native vigour inherent in all popular languages, and more particularly in the Florentine dialect; and as it may not be fully understood even by such of our readers as are versed in Italian, we will attempt a translation: — “I —possess no church–living plundered from mankind, no income of your thieves: I never toll the bell pro defunctis; nor do I sing any Gaudeamus; never in my life did I filch a single farthing either from St. Gregorio or St. Lazzaro; nor get a loaf between my teeth but what was first sweated for by the labour of my brains”. An extract from one of his letters to the Grand–duke Cosmo I his natural sovereign, gives us at once an insight into the individual and the spirit of the age. “Io sono un prete che familiarmente favello con V. S. illustrissima, e mi chiamo il Doni; son musico, scrittore dotto in volgare, et di nove [volte più] per Greco; son poeta, ch'io dovea dire innanzi; et perchè mi conosciate ch'io vi sono, oltre l'essere vassallo, affezionato, et vi vo' bene mando a' cantori di V. E. una mia canzone. Pur se voi mi fiutaste, io non so nulla di prete; ma puzzo piuttosto di pazzo”. — “I am a priest who thus familiarly address your illustrious Grace, and my name is Doni: I am a musician, a learned writer in my native tongue, and ten times more so in the Greek language; moreover, which ought to have been mentioned before, I am a poet; and that you may know that I am not only your loyal subject, but also your most affectionate well–wisher, I send a canzonet of mine to be performed by your Grace's singers. However, if you examine more minutely into my person, you will perceive that I smell more of a madman than of a priest”. These letters were published by Doni; and the Grand–duke Cosmo, while he either laughed at the singular professions of the cynical priest, or at all events suffered his extravagancies to pass with impunity, abandoned philosophy, and all that belonged to it, to the holy office of the inquisition. Cosmo commanded Galileo, who was his subject, to quit Tuscany, and repair to the dominions of the Pope, that he might either undergo the punishment of heresy, or confess that the earth was motionless, and that the sun revolved around it. It is well known that the philosopher, now aged and blind, after having upon his knees pronounced, with a loud voice, all that was dictated to him by the inquisitors, arose, and with a significant nod of the head, mattered, And yet the earth does move! Such in Italy was the mode of acting and thinking in that age. Princes the clergy, nay the very monks themselves, laughed at the following epitaph, which Doni is believed to have composed for Aretino before his death, and which they considered as an excellent jeu d'esprit:
Qui giace l'Aretin, poeta Tosco,
Che disse mal d'ognun fuorchè di Cristo,
Scusandosi col dir — non lo conosco.
Here Aretino lies, the Tuscan bard,
Who, saving Christ's, all characters did blot;
And still this reason from his lips was heard
For sparing his alone — I know him not!

This epigram, after nearly three centuries, is to this day repeated by the common people of Italy, and will doubtless be repeated for many generations to come, with less imaginary detriment to religion than that dreaded by the clergy from philosophical theories, which are unintelligible to the people.

For the rest, those Italians do not act wisely who cite the Librerie of Doni as a proof that the invention of periodical works belongs to him. It is true that these two compilations bear some resemblance to our literary journals, but they did not appear periodically; they contain but few facts, and much declamation; the accompanying criticism is neither enlightened nor just; the wit of the writer consists in a certain energy of idiomatic expressions, an incredible audacity in the invectives, which he scatters with an unsparing hand, intermixed with some flashes of genius, and in a tolerably profound knowledge of those weaknesses and follies of humanity that are sure to raise a laugh; in a word, his literary judgments are envenomed libels against his enemies, and his enemies were all those who refused him money, while his manner of flattering those who, either through vanity or fear, were induced to purchase his favour, is impudent and vulgar. Having dedicated one of his works to a gentleman from whom he did not receive the recompense he expected, he, the day after, reprinted the dedication with a virulent satire against his unfortunate Mecaenas, and inscribed his work to some nameless Jew. A man like this may assuredly be considered as the greatest, if not the most ancient among the patriarchs of venal literature, whose descendants have multiplied in a wonderful degree throughout all the countries of Europe, and are everywhere distinguished by the same characteristic marks. They aspire after fame, and the honest rewards of literature, without the knowledge that can ensure them either, or a due respect for the literary world, from which their ignorant pretension are of themselves sufficient to exclude them. The consequence is, that such men not only find themselves in the distressing situation of a man of real talents who is obliged to write for his livelihood, but are also under the necessity of professing themselves equal to tasks which they are unable to perform, and of expecting emoluments which they can never obtain. Thus it is that all literary adventurers, who hunt fortune and fame through pamphlet, newspaper, and magazine, finish by becoming beggarly quacks and barefaced impostors. Having assumed the garb of professional authors, they are induced to believe themselves really that which they are interested to appear; and in the attempt to impose upon others, they for a while succeed in imposing upon themselves. Atlast, finding their claims to celebrity utterly disappointed, their vanity is wounded to the quick, and from a love of fame dwindles into a lust for notoriety. They become quarrelsome, boisterous, and daring; finding the delusions under which they had acted at last dissipated, they are instinctively prompted to varnish over that falsehood, to which they still fondly cling, with some appearance of truth; seconded by the force of habit, this instinct improves their skill, and, emboldened by success, succeeds in deadening in their minds the faculty that discriminates between truth and falsehood: they then unintentionally become calumniators; and when such men have the misfortune to deal in that species of small literature which publishes anonymous scandal, they become fearful opponents, and still more fearful friends.

Doni had prepared three manuscripts to mortify and alarm his contemporaries, even when in his grave. In the first he had, according to mercantile forms, registered in two columns the benefits and the injuries which he had received and repaid with interest. The second contained the retractions of all the hireling praises for which he had been paid, and of all the calumnies which he had poured forth in the bitterness of his heart. In the third he had written his own life. Had not some zealots for the morals of the public been over officious in destroying these manuscripts, it is true that another page, would have been added to the catalogue of human depravity, but it would also have put us is possession of a great number of facts and anecdotes illustrative of the manners and spirit of the sixteenth century. We may add, that an acquaintance with the manners, the mind, and the heart of one of the most impudent of hirelings and vindictive of critics, would have led us to a more perfect knowledge of the whole race, and enabled us to be more on our guard against them.

If, however, Doni may be regarded as the model of all impudent editors and writers of literary criticism, he has no claim to the merit of being the original institutor of periodical works. The first literary Italian journal appeared in Rome in 1669, three years after the appearance of the
Journal des Savants and the Philosophical Transactions, and continued for nearly twenty years; a term to which rarely, if at all, any other periodical work of that nation attained. All the literary journals that succeeded this first attempt were unsuccessful, with the exception of the Galleria di Minerva , and more particularly the Giornale de' Letterati , which began in 1710, and was continued with increasing applause; indeed, had all the articles been equal in merit to those on the subject of antiquities, it would have merited a place in every public library. The contributors to this department of literature were some of the most illustrious antiquarians of Italy; — a Maffei, a Zeno, a Bianchini, and a Muratori, illustrated the epochs, the laws, and the manners of the ancient empires of the East, and of Greece and Rome, and threw a light across the gloom that had till then obscured the history of the middle ages. In fact, this was the age of gigantic antiquaries. When, therefore, we have occasion to examine into the present state of antiquarian studies in Italy, we shall purposely refer to this epoch, of which by far too little is known. The benefits which these great men conferred upon the histories of ancient nations, and of the barbarous ages that preceded the new civilization of Europe, have been purposely concealed by certain eloquent authors, who, had it not been for the labours of these unwearied writers, would not have possessed the materials for their celebrated works.

But while such attention was shewn to antiquarian researches, poetry, eloquence, moral and political philosophy, and all those departments of literature that speak to the imagination, the heart, and the public and domestic interests of mankind, were, if not altogether neglected, certainly cultivated with little taste and less ardour. No work can hope to become popular, that requires readers learned by profession. The majority of men must be led to the search of the beautiful, the just, and the true, and taught how to appreciate them, not by means of erudition, dry matters of fact, and logical arguments, but through the medium of strong and pleasing sensations, and by means of such a style and manner of narration as, by interesting the imagination and the heart, can excite the memory, the judgment, and all the other faculties of the mind, to a constant and pleasing exercise. Of works written in this spirit for the instruction of a whole nation, under the form of periodical publications, the Italians, so rich in other literary treasures, are still deficient. The too numerous universities and capital cities of Italy have, as we before hinted, the effect of preventing all men of eminent talents, all great artists, all new publications, and all the advances and inventions of genius, from concentrating in one focus, and diffusing their united splendour from one single city. The inconveniencies of this multitude of capital cities and courts, are increased by laws, institutions, and customs, incompatible with a periodical work. Writers might intermeddle in political matters, though only in the case of a conflict of local interests between one Italian state and another; and then, the. dispute being naturally imbittered by pitiful animosities, and intermingled with circumstances minute and unimportant in themselves, and scarcely intelligible to those not concerned in the contest, the curiosity and interest of the other Italians is but faintly, if at all, excited.

And yet, even arguments of so poor a nature were capable of being treated with a certain nobleness, and of acquiring in manner the merit which they wanted in matter; for certain it is, that the mind of a free and enlightened writer can ascend to general principles, and deduce useful consequences, from the examination of minute facts and questions apparently irrelevant. The historian who of all others has most profoundly penetrated into the hearts of princes, and most strongly and originally described the vicissitudes of the greatest empire that ever existed, professes not to disdain common events and minute particulars which appear of no moment, since in these are frequently to be discovered the origin of great revolutions, and some of the instructions most useful for the conduct of life.
Quae referam, parva forsitan et levia memoratu videri non nescius sum.... nobis in arcto, et inglorius labor. Non tamen sine usu fuerit, introspicere illa primo aspectu levia, ex quis magnarum saepe rerum motus (al monitus) oriuntur. Tacitus, Annal., IV, 32 [con omissioni] But not even would the vigorous intellect of a Tacitus have been able to draw profound and sublime reflections from the most minute and common facts, in order to aggrandize and ennoble them, had the writer been hemmed in by terror and by chains. Now in Italy, at the epoch of which we speak, and even at the present day, to illustrate political questions by general principles, to speculate upon better forms of administration, to propose new theories, to allude to the different situations of other European governments; in a word, to point out any imperfection in the actual constitution and laws of a country in which an author writes, although that country be the land that gave him birth, were all crimes amounting to high treason. The weakness of various states obliged them to limit their mutual wars to battles of the pen; but on these occasions the writers of the contesting parties were not allowed to deviate in the minutest particular from the point in question; so that, instead of thinking and speaking with the liberty and eloquence of statesmen, they merely acted the dull part of pleaders bristling with sophistries, who bring forward arguments that have been dictated to them, and declaim with a virulence proportioned to the pay they receive. Hence, if a writer in favour of a particular government happened to be prosecuted by another prince, the individual, in spite of his literary merit and his devotion to his country, was almost always sure to be sacrificed to the remonstrances of the foreign ambassador. Of this truth Giannone is a striking example. Having published his civil history of Naples, he was obliged to live an outcast, and to die in a prison. This work was universally read and praised in secret by all Italy; but the journalists, so far from making mention of it, were fearful of even uttering the name of the author in conversation. We find, in one of the letters of the celebrated Zeno, the editor and principal contributor to the Galleria di Minerva , of which mention has just been made, and which was published in Venice, the following characteristic anecdote: Giannone, when under persecution, had sought for an asylum in Venice, as being a more free and independent city than the rest, and as he himself was a Venetian subject. The doctrines which, in his history, he had illustrated and defended against the temporal power of the Pope, were accordant with the constitutions of the Venetian republic. But the Venetians, content with being at that time as free as was possible from the yoke of the Vatican, and fearful of renewing the old contest with the See of Rome, meanly left to his fate the defender of the fundamental principles of their government in ecclesiastic matters. Giannone, oppressed with years and infirmities, poor, and an outcast, was banished from all the dominions of that republic of which he was a subject. But even before the senate had recourse to this cowardly expedient, the literati of Venice, and of the rest of Italy, avoided visiting Giannone, or took refuge in the country for fear of being visited or even met by him. Many admired him for his courageous devotion to the cause of truth; all compassionated him in secret; but no one ventured to offer succour or consolation. Hence, there are times and governments in which even just, generous, and enlightened men, are constrained to provide for their individual security, by assuming the cruel pusillanimity of the barbarians who tremble beneath the terrors of Asiatic despotism.

We shall continue to pause upon these times, since, in all respects, they present an image of the state of slavery in which the editors of periodical works in Italy are at present placed, and will afford us an opportunity of describing, at one and the same time, the past and the present. Moral philosophy was, at that period, scarcely more free than the political. Reflections upon human nature, researches into the labyrinths of the heart, and such precepts for the conduct of life as were not, in all respects, conformable to the catechism of the priesthood, subjected the writer to the danger of being accused of heresy. Neither could literary criticism, nor disquisitions upon works of imagination, obtain enlightened and impartial judges; for as the religious in Italy, as in all the rest of the world, had the education of youth entirely in their own hands, they conspired to extol to the skies whatever was written by their own confraternity, or those brought up by them, and to depress the merit of those writers who would not condescend to be subject to their literary tyranny. We do not deny, and are even disposed to acknowledge, the benefits which the Jesuits may have conferred on other countries, particularly on France, though we have not examined all the facts necessary to ascertain how far these praises are just. But with respect to Italy, the annals of which we have attentively studied, we can, without fear of contradiction assert, that the beautiful, the sublime, the national literature, disappeared from Italy at the very period that succeeded the institution of the schools of the Jesuits. The dominion of strangers, and particularly of the Spaniards, and the consequent ruin of the independence of almost all the Italian cities which were contemporary with these schools, must doubtless have powerfully contributed to sink and impoverish letters. However, neither foreign despotism, nor the influence of the Inquisition, could force genius to sit down contented with the state of debasement to which it was reduced by the systematic craft and persevering arts of the brotherhood.
Igneus est olli vigor et coelestis origo.
VIRGILIO, Aeneidos, lib. VI.
When genius has once begun to spread its genial rays among a people, to enlighten them by its splendour, and make its divine voice heard among them, no human power is able to reduce it to silence.

Education may be so contrived as to produce only mediocre abilities. The colleges of the Jesuits peopled Italy with rhymesters, declaimers, and petty authors, full of affectation and bad taste; but poetry, eloquence, and vigour of style, were no more. Some few writers, a Filicaja and a Guidi, for instance, attained to considerable celebrity; but it was not so much from any eminent merit, as from the general scarcity of good poets; and if that age produced any men worthy of the admiration and the gratitude of posterity, it will be found that they all wrote and lived in a state of perpetual and perilous warfare with the Jesuits. Some men of this order were useful writers; none were great: and among the many Italians who began and completed their literary education in these colleges, there is not an example of one who wrote with originality of style or profundity of thought. It would seem as if the Jesuits had discovered the art of exalting petty abilities, and humbling those of a higher order, thus reducing them all to the level of mediocrity; of substituting the vanity of academic applause for the love of glory. Hence, the periodical works which were either undertaken or patronized by the Jesuits, invariably tended to diffuse their doctrines, as well religious, political, and moral, as rhetorical, and to oppress their adversaries. The consequence was, that their literary criticism was partial, unjust, and limited to certain precepts and scholastic doctrines, beyond which it was not permitted to advance. Directly, or indirectly, the influence of this body was perceptible in all the journals of the day: they became the arbitrary dispensers of that praise or censure from which there was no appeal. If a solitary exception was sometimes found; if some journalist remained uninfected with the jesuitical spirit, which tended to denaturalize every thing, — he was not permitted to unmask the evil with impunity, and was obliged to connive at it in silence.

The age was, however, tending to one of those periodical changes which nature is continually, though almost imperceptibly, preparing in the world; and which always explode with a vehemerice proportionate to the resistance they sustain — like gunpowder, which, the more forcibly it is compressed in the mine, spreads a wider ruin around. The tendency of the age brought about a revolution of opinions that destroyed of a sudden the omnipotency of the Jesuits: the same cause induced the emperor Joseph II to promote many ecclesiastical and political reforms in his Italian dominions. The Venetian republic reduced its states into a kind of free port to favour literary commerce. The press resumed its more than wonted activity; the boundaries of the national literature were enlarged by means of translations, and by the reprinting of many French works which had been anathematized by the church of Rome. It was at this period that certain individuals, who to enlightened views united patrimonial wealth and nobility of birth, established a kind of philosophical colony in Milan, which corresponded with the Encyclopedists and Economists of France, and undertook a periodical work entiled Il Caffè . The freedom of thought displayed by the writers of the articles contained in it, caused them to be looked up to as men of generous and exalted minds: and while readers admired in the work a courage unknown in those times, they could not separate it in their minds from literary merit. But when the works of foreign great writers found the passage into Italy less obstructed, and began to be spread abroad, the Caffè , like the journals of France and England, appeared but a puerile attempt. Some years after, out of honour to the memory of the printer, the librarian, the editors, the writers of the articles, and the correctors of the proofs, who were all Milanese, a new edition of the Caffè was given in Milan, where, even to this day, it is much praised, though rarely read; by the other inhabitants of Italy it is never spoken of. The fact, that many among the contributors to this unsuccessful journal were men of superior minds, proves the correctness of our observation, that periodical works are undertaken and carried on with difficulty, because genius, knowledge, and diligence, are rendered of no avail, unless the works themselves are conducted according to the spirit of the age, and, above all, with a most correct knowledge of the taste and mind of the readers. To this may be added, that the subdivision of the Peninsula into so many governments, each of which had its petty officers, its academicians, its inquisitors and censors (all of whom followed their separate laws and methods), and the absolute want of public modes of conveyance to enable works of a periodical description to be circulated with the necessary expedition from one part of the nation to the other, obliged them to be content with the limited number of readers and subscribers to be found in the state in which the work was published; and consequently the expenses resulting from such an undertaking must, for the greater part, have exceeded the receipts.

The only periodical publication, which, though now almost forgotten, deserves to be reprinted, on account of the purity of the language, and the faithful description of the very singular manners of Venice, is the Osservatore , which appeared weekly in that city, and was entirely from the pen of the Conte Gasparo Gozzi. Without being a profound thinker; he looked with a penetrative eye into the mysteries of the human heart, and with a view to instil a gentle and indulgent morality, he employed the arms of ridicule, — but it was a ridicule dictated rather by coinpassion than by a contempt and hatred of mankind. His style, though without fire, was not deficient of that constant warmth which insensibly attracts; his diction has the limpid flow and the subdued melody of a stream springing from a living source, and flowing tranquilly through the meadows. He deserves to be ranked among the chosen few of those Italians who study and write their difficult language, in such a manner as to cull all its native graces, without spoiling them by any affectation either of philosophical patckwork or pedantic purity, avoiding that verbosity so conspicuous in the multitude of Italian writers, To those Englishmen who complain of the few prose authors in Italian that can be studied without a feeling of tediousness, we would recommend the Osservatore
of Gasparo Gozzi.

The high eulogiums with which a celebrated German poet has lately spoken of Carlo Gozzi, and which are repeated by many critics, ought not to be passed over without reflection by those who aspire to literary renown. The two brothers wrote with an entirely different object. What Gasparo laboured at incessantly was to refine the taste, the style, and the manners of his countrymen. Carlo ridiculed study, style, and taste: he wrote in mere caprice, and wrought up into comedies certain namby–pamby fables which the Venetian nurses conned over to the children to lull them to sleep. The people, flocking to the theatre to the representation of these dramas, laughed with childish glee at the silliness before them; the poet, in his turn, laughed at the folly of the people; and men of education laughed at the poet: nor did any one dream, that, after his death, this merry wight should be extolled by foreigners as a man of a most original genius; while the elegant writings produced by his brother with so much study, and such laborious attention, and which deservedly obtained for him from his contemporaries the title of the Venetian Addison, should be scarcely remembered by the generation that came after him.

The value of the Osservatore of Gasparo Gozzi was made manifest to the Italians by a rigid critic, who had perfected, if not begun, his literary education in England, and who was the first to introduce into Italy the new code of criticism which he had received from Dr Johnson. Many of our readers will at once see that we allude to Baretti, who died in London in the year 1789. He lived to a very advanced age, endowed with an irresistible power of attraction and repulsion, insomuch so, that whoever was not venturous enough to become either his bosom friend or his irreconcileable foe, was under the necessity of renouncing his acquaintance. Many who knew him, and who continue either to love or to detest his memory, are still alive; but few know by what means it was that nature and fortune conspired to form so strange a character. Born the poor descendant of the family of the Marchesi di Carretto in Piedmont, who had forfeited their patrimonial possessions, he would sometimes soothe his pride by travelling with his family arms and title. But he was born more proud than vain; and his mind was continually agitated and harassed by the twofold fear either of being thought a plebeian, or deservedly ridiculed as a man who affected patrician titles and honours while he gained his livelihood by the sweat of his brow. The profession of an ecclesiastic in Italy, and the title of Abate , neutralize those of noble birth with persons of the plebeian order; and, at the commencement, Baretti turned his thoughts to this state of life; but feeling unable to take the vow of celibacy required in the Catholic church, he suddenly took to the study of architecture; when reflecting that he was purblind, and that the sight of a good artist is not assisted by spectacles, he turned to the profession of the law. Soon growing wearied of the long and Gothic modes of grammar at that time thought necessary for the acquirement of the Latin, in which language jurisprudence was then taught, he resigned himself to the situation of clerk in a banking–house, where he spent more time in poring over books of literature than over the ledger of his employer. Thinking that he neither could, nor was in duty bound to obey masters, who were not born gentlemen like himself, and were much less liberal and much more ignorant, he finally adopted the unhappy resolution of gaining his livelihood by writing for the booksellers. The untractableness of his disposition, to which may be attributed his natural capriciousness, and the impatience and restlessness of his mind, which even the powerful and soothing cares of a mother were incapable of softening, was imbittered by the hatred, or, as others think, by the love which he conceived for his mother–in–law. The father of Baretti, who had been left a widower, had married a young wife, who, justified by the usages of those times, and of the country in which she lived, became the Platonic adultress of a courtier who was a favourite of the king, and of the ladies of Piedmont. The young Baretti, whether enamoured or jealous of his mother–in–law, or perhaps to vindicate the honour of his father, attempted to wash out an injury in the blood of the offender, for which neither laws, nor judges, nor priests promised any redress: in this, however, he did not succeed, and was obliged to seek his safety by flying his country. Thus, being without the advantages of education, and instructed in no useful art, he found himself in the flower of his age without a country. Misfortune, which softens some minds, stamped a character of sterness and severity on his. He was ever sacrificing his peace to the ambition of never pardoning an injury, or making allowance for the ignorance and the weakness of men. The mist of passion through which he always regarded human weaknesses, the obstinate vehemence with which he maintained his opinions, and the inflexible asperity of this admonitions, tended to render his readers less docile. But when, in a happier mood, he became more indulgent to the companions of his pleasures, his whole soul and all his words assumed a cheerfulness and gaiety; and his domestic life was sweetened by all the gentler virtues, and was open to the exercise of all the amiable propensities, of the human heart. Hence all his friends admired and pitied him as a kind of literary Cato; but towards others he appeared a cynic, who to the staff of Diogenes joined the weapons and the ferocity of a soldier. All the world knows the circumstance of his having taken summary vengeance into his own hands, when assaulted in the streets of London by a gang of pick–pockets and loose women, and whereby he rendered himself guilty of the crime of homicide. It is even the opinion of some, that on this unfortunate occasion he appears to have shown less disposition to defend than,to avenge himself; nor would the provocation given him by these wretched persons, nor the eloquence with which he defended himself, have been sufficient to save him, had not the jury been induced to have regard to the number and character of the various respectable, and particularly literary individuals, who came forward to attest that Baretti was a man of unblamable life, and of a disposition which was defective in no other respect than in a natural impatience in bearing injuries, and in a readiness to repel them. Thus he continued on till his forty–fifth year, without any other provision for his old age except the expedient of teaching Italian, and of compiling dictionaries, grammatical works, and editions of Italian authors for the use of his scholars; with whom, however, he had not the art of living upon friendly terms for any length of time together. Whoever is fond of gossip may take his full in the volumes of Boswell, who dicenda, tacenda locutus, has published I know not what domestic squabbles between Baretti and Mrs Thrale, whose daughter was at that time under his instructions. It is really to be regretted, that after Baretti had lived as a guest, a master, a dependant, and a friend, in the house of Mrs Thrale, and after his having quitted the family for more than twenty years, that he should have carried his resentment even to his extreme old age, when, being on the very verge of the grave, he launched his invectives against poor Mrs Thrale, who had now become Signora Piozzi, and was infatuated with the vanity of acquainting the world that she had carried on a correspondence with Dr Johnson.

But when Baretti, seconding his natural inclination for discussion, found a favourable opportunity, then would his genius and his mind expand and rise with his subject. His discourse against Voltaire in defence of Shakespeare, tended to diffuse the principles of poetical criticism applied by all the English, but unknown till then in France and Italy; and he espoused them with an eloquence abounding with the same irony, the same wit, the same insolence and contemptuousness of manner, which had rendered the dictator of European literature so formidable an opponent. This discourse is written in French. One of the gifts of Baretti was a great facility in making himself master of foreign languages. Whether he wrote them all correctly we have no means of judging, but we are disposed to doubt the fact. It is no trifling acquirement for a man to be perfectly master of all the riches of his native language; in that of another country he will always have to feel his way, above all if he has to express ideas of a profound character. Baretti was no deep thinker; he conceived his thoughts in a whimsical manner, and expressed them in all the languages of which he was master, with that warmth and freedom which makes us pardon grammatical defects — like those riders who, not being acoustomed to horsemanship, start off into a full gallop, and are admired for their courage.

Nevertheless, in spite of his daring confidence in his own strength, Baretti, partly through admiration and the necessity of instruction, and partly also through fashion and a spirit of speculation, professed himself a disciple and imitator of Dr Johnson. But the universal and intuitive mind of Johnson, the superiority which he held over all his contemporaries, the precision and the originality of his eloquence, and above all the gravity of his character, gave a degree of veneration even to the trifles which fell from his lips; while the arrogant, abrupt, and sometimes plebeian manners of Baretti, tended to detract from the dignity and splendour of truth. Johnson and Baretti, having been self–taught, had the important advantage of thinking and expressing themselves in a manner entirely their own. Their minds had not been preoccupied by the slavish forms, the pedantry, and the esprit de corps of the college and the university; but, like all self–taught persons, they were led to believe, that whatever they had learned without masters, had never before been known or taught by any other person. Their confused, tumultuary, and frequently interrupted reading m a variety of books during their youth, had accustomed the faculties of their mind to a want of connexion, — to disorder and impatience; and whenever they beheld a ray of truth, they hastened ambitiously to reduce it to general maxims and axioms, and the consequences at which they arrived were not always exactly deduced from their principles. The facts on which they reasoned were not multiplied by assiduous researches, nor examined and confronted with diligence; and the dates oft–times, without which effects appear causes and causes effects, are rarely found to be exact in their writing. Hence, when they disputed, professionally, with all and on all subjects, their magisterial sentences are found involved in errors and contradictions. They had frequently recourse to sophisms, and sometimes to sarcasms; and they contended more for the vanity of the victory than for the love of truth. Both the one and the other were literary adventurers, and they made a parade of their riches, with all the boast and pomp of parvenus. But the riches of Johnson's mind sprung up spontaneously, new, diversified; infinite, as are the products of genius whatever its education may have been. As to Baretti, he did not possess a single spark of genius: he had received from nature that kind of talent which knows how to employ with dexterity, and give a certain air of novelty to what has been invented by others, but is altogether incapable of discovering or inventing any thing of itself. He was acute, persevering, wary, and sometimes happy in his attempts to convince others of their errors. He appears to have been impelled to continual battles of the pen by an irresistible instinct, to which all his faculties were so accustomed, that he could neither read nor think in order to add to the stores of his own knowledge, without at the same time reproaching others with their poverty and the weakness of their understanding. The best of his few literary attainments were derived from his conversations with Johnson. Whatever Johnson said, whatever he wrote, bespoke the man of superior mind, who felt conscious of being born in a lowly rank, and of having spent the better part of the spring–tide of his life in occupations not suited to his high intellect and the nobleness of his mind; and it would appear that, in order to efface in his own mind, as well as in that of others, the previous humbleness of his condition, he accustomed himself always to speak with more pomp and authority, and with less good taste, than he would have done had he been of more respectable birth, and shared a fortune less unpropitious. Hence he gave a splendour, a magnificence, and a sonorous rotundity of style, even to trifles and common ideas. But his Italian disciple, who had been condemned from his early youth to wander as an outcast; who had grown up in a country, where courts, nobles, and even magistrates, frequently outraged the laws, — every man who was unwilling to suffer injustice and insult in silence, occasionally sought to avenge himself with arms and bloodshed. Having seldom a home, except in inns and taverns, among people of the lower class, and sometimes even with persons of the worst description; and being. like his master Johnson, inclined to sensuality and love of the table, but less scrupulous of the society in which he enjoyed them, Baretti had acquired vulgar manners, which to him became a second nature, and which had an influence upon his writings. In fact, whether from an instinctive feeling, or taught by experience, he felt that an imitation of the solemnity of Johnson's style would have exposed him to ridicule; and yet, in his own language, he neglected those authors who wrote with dignity, and studied the poetry of Berni, and the prose of Benvenuto Cellini, authors who could furnish him no other examples than of idiomatical expression. He acquired neither the spontaneous grace of the former, nor the energy of the latter; and if the autobiography of Cellini began to obtain a reputation which it had not before enjoyed, and for which it was indebted to Baretti, who conceded to the Florentine artist the palm above all the Tuscan writers, such praises were exaggerated, but not without their advantage, for many Italians learnt from this work, that the thinking strongly, and conceiving powerfully what is written, tends more effectually to form the style, than all the grammatical and rhetorical treatises of their academies. The Italian expressions of Baretti correspond to the energies of his mind, and though he cannot be considered as a very pure writer, and his works being for the greater part upon grammatical subjects, and regarding the literary squabbles in which he passed his life, are but of little importance, still the writings of Baretti continue to be reprinted and read on account of their style. Whoever is sufficiently acquainted with the Italian and English to be capable of pronouncing a decided opinion, would perhaps say, that the model whom Baretti took for his style and manner was Swift.

Furnished with these funds of ability, character, learning, and style, Baretti quitted England and returned to Italy; where, in the year 1765, he began a periodical work entitled,
La Frusta Letteraria di Aristarco Scannabue
(The Literary Scourge of the Ox–slaughtering Aristarchus). The Italians, and particularly the Florentines, gave the name of oxen to heavy men and stupid writers. In unison with his new name, and with the title of his journal, were the opinions true, false, and doubtful, the numerous paradoxes, prejudices, and sophisms of Johnson, which he disseminated among his countrymen, The opinions, sometimes precipitate, and not always just, of the English critic, and which, as they were delivered in the manner of oracles, procured him the veneration of the multitude of readers, when repeated by Baretti with menacing arrogance, provoked a most severe examination; and those opinions which were only doubtful and partial, were reprobated as unjust and malignant. Even the many truths, and new and luminous illustrations of Johnson, applicable to the literature of every people and every age, and which at once carry conviction, because they appear suggested by the inspiration of a mind little short of divine, were applied by Baretti in such a manner as to excite a belief, that his object was not so much to benefit his country, as to underrate the merits of the esteemed men of the nation; to overthrow all the theories consecrated by time; and to disseminate scandal and literary heresies in the academies and schools. Perhaps Italy was not yet in a condition to receive these truths; at all events, in order not to have met with an obstinate repulse, they required a writer capable of diffusing them with a more insinuating eloquence, and with a less fanatical confidence in the infallibility of his preceptor. The artist who with a humorous pencil had sketched Mrs Thrale, dressed as a mountaineer, leading to some fair the formidable Doctor in the shape of a bear, and Mr Boswell as half drunk, and playing with all his might upon the Scotch bagpipe, would have rendered the picture complete, if he had painted Baretti upon the back of the bear transformed into an ape.

Heretofore the Italian poets had acknowledged themselves inferior to those of Greece and Rome. They believed, that either the usages, the religion, or the language of the ancients, were better adapted to poetry, or that nature had ceased to produce geniuses of gigantic mould. They did not reflect that, independently of these circumstances, partly true, partly exaggerated, and in part imaginary, the poetry of the ancients consisted in the design, the colouring of the thought, in the unity and proportion of the images, and consequently in a perfection to which no genius can attain if fettered by the imperious necessity of rhyme. The attempts made to approximate the manner of the ancients by means of blank verse had for many ages proved abortive, till at last, in the time of Baretti, the successful essays of some poets excited a hope that Italian versification might be managed in such a manner as to produce many, if not all the wonderful effects of the hexameter. A short time thereafter, blank verse was brought to such perfection, that the language, the thoughts, and the poetry acquired a wider range, more abundant riches, and an aspect altogether new. In fact, by means of blank verse, the Italian literature attained a marked and most important epoch, which has not yet been described with sufficient attention: we shall therefore reserve this subject for a separate article, with which we shall present our readers in a future number. But Baretti either did not know, or was determined not to see, the improvements that had thus taken place; and the aversion manifested by Dr Johnson for blank verse, was converted by his disciple into a superstitious and ridiculous detestation. If men versed in these studies were to confront with the original, one of the satires of Juvenal imitated by Dr Johnson, they would at once perceive that the verse of the ancient poet, unshackled by rhyme, allowed him to present all his thoughts designed, formed, and embodied in living imagery — the general maxims, facts, and allusions, in the Latin satirist, are presented under the form of angry deities and genii; we think we behold their menacing attitude, and hear their warning voice; but the same thoughts, when cramped into rhyme, are transmuted into epigrammatic sentences, which, in the harmony and vigour of the expression, give us to feel the orator, the philosopher, the profound observer of the human heart, and the finished versifier, but rarely, if at all, the poet. It is true that Johnson did not seem formed by nature for a great poet; and being perhaps conscious of this, he called into action the other powerful faculties of his mind, in order to constitute himself a profound and original judge of that art in which his first attempts were not equal to his ambition. Baretti conimenced his literary career, by translating the dramatic works of Corneille: rhymed poetry, and that of the French writers in particular, rarely furnishes a translator with sufficient colouring, design, and imagery, to be transferred with effect into blank verse. Baretti translated into blank verse, and wretchedly: he imputed the failure to a want of rhyme, but he ought rather to have blamed the poetry of his original and the rhyme, but above all, his own antipoetical talent. Indeed it would appear that he discovered this truth, since he entirely desisted from verse, and turned all his attention to the formation of such a style in prose, as became formidable to those poets in the rank of whom he could not obtain admission. To the same cause may be traced the complacency of Johnson in modelling his solemn periods to inform us, that Milton, when a lad, was flogged by his master at college, — that Milton, in the vigour of life, was reduced to procure a livelihood by teaching a school, — that Milton, in his old age, though a dauntless defender of liberty, was naturally a tyrant, because, in his infirmities, in blindness and in solitude, he sought for aid and assistance from the weaker sex, and other such malignant inductions, — not to mention the proofs which, with little judgment and less dignity, he extorted from a waiting–woman, in order to convict Pope of gluttony, childish caprices, and other weaknesses common to all men; — all these are proofs, that the critic, enraged against nature for not having destined him for poetry, revenged himself upon poets of the higher order; and when their works, and the consent of mankind, prevented him from vilifying their genius, he sought to throw doubt and suspicion upon their minds and actions. Johnson, however, was content with dealing praise or censure on the dead; not so Baretti: with his Literary Scourge he lashed the living with unsparing fury, and the wounds which his pen inflicted were sometimes repelled with threats of the cudgel and the poniard. We find a person of Brescia, half a poet and half a gentleman, intimating to him, that if he either praised or censured him in that journal, the ox–slaughtering Aristarchus should himself be found some night or other butchered in the streets of Brescia; a city at that time famous for daily acts of this kind, which escaped with impunity. The threat was cowardly, and Baretti despised it. But though such quarrels do not generally end in blood, still they are productive of a virulence of invective, of an envenomed malignity, and of a low and vulgar abuse, that, through charity to the cause of literature, ought to be consigned to contempt and oblivion. As for ourselves, we recall them to mind with feelings of the deepest reprobation, out of a good feeling to the modern Italians, who, if in this respect they do not sin as their forefathers did, still have not purged themselves of the old leaven of iniquity. Indeed, how can this well be done in a country where every capital city, every academy, every college, every municipality, affects pre–eminence in literature; where all, being forced to silence and inactivity in things of importance, confer importance upon trifles; where foreign rulers take a pleasure in humbling and debasing men born to educate, to instruct, and to be an honour to their country; and where, consequently, the wars of the pen, ridiculous as they are become in other countries, are kept alive, and in Italy degenerate into civil odiums, which increase the discords, weakness, slavery, and ignorance of the whole nation.

The religious feeling predominant in the character of Johnson, and tending to superstition, was perhaps equally sincere, though less intense, in the mind of Baretti. As Johnson in England would not listen to a sermon by the illustrious historian of Charles V because. he preached Calvinism, Baretti in Italy thought himself called upon to lash all those with his Literary Scourge who did not scrupulously venerate all the dogmas of the Catholic church. Nor did he succeed in appeasing the monks and priests, who then were, and as it appears are now about again to be, the exclusive poets and critics of the nation, as well as the teachers, guests, confessors, buffoons, and frequently, too, the major–domos and computisti in the houses of the rich and noble, and above all, professors in the colleges and universities, and not unfrequently the spies of governments. In vain did Baretti, while censuring the verses of certain monks and priests, profess himself the champion of religion, and the venerator of their convents and institutes. He was at last obliged to confess, that it was to the priests he was indebted for all the calumnies with which he had been blackened, all the risks he had run of being imprisoned as a vagabond, of being condemned as guilty of high–treason, or burnt for heresy by the holy: inquisition.
